div.p: Modular invariance is a necessary condition for the consistency of any closed string theory. In particular, it imposes stringent constraints on the spectrum of orbifold theories, and in principle determines their spectrum uniquely up to discrete torsion classes. In practice, however, there are often ambiguities in the construction of orbifolds that are a consequence of the fact that the action of the orbifold elements on degenerate ground states is not unambiguous. We explain that there exists an additional consistency condition, related to the spectrum of D-branes in the theory, which eliminates these ambiguities. For supersymmetric orbifolds this condition turns out to be equivalent to the condition that supersymmetry is unbroken in the twisted sectors, but for non-supersymmetric orbifolds it appears to be a genuinely new consistency condition.
CITUSC/00-002
DAMTP-2000-4

p.span: California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91125, USA

div.p: and

p.span: CIT/USC Center for Theoretical Physics, Univ. of Southern California, Los Angeles CA
Department of Applied Mathematics and Theoretical Physics

div.p: January 2000

The orbifold construction is one of the most powerful techniques in string theory that allows one to obtain interesting new theories with reduced symmetries [1]. This procedure can be applied whenever a string theory possesses a discrete symmetry group ŒìŒìGamma\Gamma. The construction proceeds in two steps: first we restrict the space of states to those that are invariant under ŒìŒìGamma\Gamma, and then we add suitably projected twisted sectors, as needed by modular invariance. The initial projection is equivalent to adding sectors to the partition function in which the boundary condition in the timelike world-sheet direction tùë°italic-tt is twisted by generators of ŒìŒìGamma\Gamma. One of the generators of the modular group of the torus, S:œÑ‚Ü¶-1/œÑ:ùëÜmaps-toùúè1ùúèitalic-S METARELOP:colon italic-tau ARROW:maps-to ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-tauS:\tau\mapsto-1/\tau, exchanges the timelike direction tùë°italic-tt with the spacelike world-sheet direction œÉùúéitalic-sigma\sigma. In order for the partition function to be modular invariant, the theory must therefore also contain sectors in which the boundary condition in œÉùúéitalic-sigma\sigma is twisted by the generators of ŒìŒìGamma\Gamma; these are the twisted sectors. Finally, invariance under the other generator of the modular group, T:œÑ‚Ü¶œÑ+1:ùëámaps-toùúèùúè1italic-T METARELOP:colon italic-tau ARROW:maps-to italic-tau ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1T:\tau\mapsto\tau+1, requires us to add sectors in which both boundary conditions are twisted; in essence this amounts to projecting the twisted sectors by ŒìŒìGamma\Gamma as well.

Whilst this algorithm determines the theory in principle, there are a number of ambiguities that are not fixed by modular invariance of the one-loop vacuum amplitude alone. For example, if we are dealing with a string theory in the RNS formalism, every sector of the theory must be GSO-projected. In each sector that possesses fermionic zero modes, and therefore a degenerate ground state, the GSO-projection acts as the chirality operator on the ground state. A priori, the definition of this operator is only fixed up to a sign, and this sign choice affects the spectrum of the theory significantly. On the other hand, the partition function is insensitive to this choice, and therefore the condition of one-loop vacuum modular invariance does not fix this ambiguity.

It is generally believed that these ambiguities are resolved by the conditions that come from non-vacuum and higher-loop amplitudes, and that the remaining freedom is described in terms of discrete torsion [2]. In practice, it is however difficult to determine the consistent GSO-projections explicitly. In fact, the analysis of [2] describes the freedom in modifying the action of the orbifold (and GSO-projections) in the twisted sectors relative to a certain solution which is assumed to be consistent, namely the one in which all phases are taken to be +11ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1+1. In particular, this requires that the above sign ambiguities have been chosen so as to give a consistent solution, but it is a priori not obvious how this should be done.

As we shall explain in this paper, there exists a simple non-perturbative consistency condition that fixes these ambiguities, at least for a certain class of theories, uniquely. This condition arises from a careful analysis of the D-brane spectrum of these theories. The D-brane spectrum can be determined using the boundary state formalism [3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8], in which D-branes are described by coherent states of the closed string sector. Once the various projection operators of the closed string theory have been fixed, the D-brane spectrum is uniquely determined. However, not every such spectrum is allowed, since there exist transitions between different D-brane configurations. Specifically, when a D-brane in the bulk collides with a fixed-plane of the orbifold it must be allowed to break into fractional D-branes. In order for this to occur, however, both types of branes must exist in the spectrum. As we shall see, this requirement fixes the ambiguities in the GSO-projection of the twisted sectors uniquely.

For orbifold projections that preserve supersymmetry, these ambiguities can also be fixed by requiring the twisted sectors to preserve the same supersymmetry. This is the case, for example, for Type IIA or IIB on T4/ùñπ‚Å¢ùñπ2superscriptùëá4ùñπsubscriptùñπ2italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide sansserif-Z sansserif-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT^{4}/{\sf Z\!\!Z}_{2}, where the ùñπ‚Å¢ùñπ2ùñπsubscriptùñπ2sansserif-Z sansserif-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\sf Z\!\!Z}_{2} generator acts by reflection of the four compact coordinates. In these cases, the supersymmetry considerations pick out precisely the theory that is also non-perturbatively consistent. For orbifolds that break supersymmetry completely, however, there does not appear to be an analogous perturbative criterion that selects the non-perturbatively consistent theory.

Our interest in this problem arose from recent work of Klebanov, Nekrasov and Shatashvili [16], who considered Type IIB on T6/ùñπ‚Å¢ùñπ4superscriptùëá6ùñπsubscriptùñπ4italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide sansserif-Z sansserif-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT^{6}/{\sf Z\!\!Z}_{4}, where the ùñπ‚Å¢ùñπ4ùñπsubscriptùñπ4sansserif-Z sansserif-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\sf Z\!\!Z}_{4} generator acts by the reflection of the six compact directions. This orbifold breaks all the supersymmetries of Type IIB, and is in fact equivalent to Type 0B on T6/ùñπ‚Å¢ùñπ2superscriptùëá6ùñπsubscriptùñπ2italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide sansserif-Z sansserif-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT^{6}/{\sf Z\!\!Z}_{2}. As we shall discuss in detail below, their choice for the GSO-projection in the twisted sectors does not satisfy the above condition, and therefore does not define a (non-perturbatively) consistent theory. This resolves the question of which state is charged under the U‚Å¢(1)ùëà1italic-U OPEN:( NUMBER:1 CLOSE:)U(1) gauge field that comes from the twisted R-R sector, since the consistent theory does not have such a gauge field.

section.h2: 2. D-branes on ùñπ‚Å¢ùñπ2ùñπsubscriptùñπ2sansserif-Z sansserif-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\sf Z\!\!Z}_{2} orbifolds.

div.p: Let us begin by describing briefly the D-brane spectrum of a ùñπ‚Å¢ùñπ2ùñπsubscriptùñπ2sansserif-Z sansserif-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\sf Z\!\!Z}_{2} orbifold, where the ùñπ‚Å¢ùñπ2ùñπsubscriptùñπ2sansserif-Z sansserif-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\sf Z\!\!Z}_{2} generator acts by the inversion of nùëõitalic-nn coordinates. (More details can be found in [8]; see also [9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15].) For simplicity we shall consider the non-compact case I‚Å¢Rn/ùñπ‚Å¢ùñπ2IsuperscriptRùëõùñπsubscriptùñπ2I R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide sansserif-Z sansserif-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\rm I\!R}^{n}/{\sf Z\!\!Z}_{2}, which only has one fixed plane (of spatial dimension 9-n9ùëõNUMBER:9 ADDOP:minus italic-n9-n) at the origin.111If mùëöitalic-mm of the nùëõitalic-nn directions on which the ùñπ‚Å¢ùñπ2ùñπsubscriptùñπ2sansserif-Z sansserif-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\sf Z\!\!Z}_{2} acts are compact there will be 2msuperscript2ùëöNUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end2^{m} fixed planes. There exist three possible types of D-branes, which differ in their boundary state components. Bulk D-branes have components only in the untwisted sectors,

semantics.annotation: VERTBAR:| italic-D italic-p CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals OPEN:( VERTBAR:| italic-B italic-p CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NS ADDOP:minus NS ;U POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus VERTBAR:| italic-B italic-p CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start R ADDOP:minus R ;U POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) PUNCT:,

div.p: fractional D-branes have components in all untwisted and twisted sectors,

semantics.annotation: VERTBAR:| italic-D italic-p CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end OPEN:( VERTBAR:| italic-B italic-p CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NS ADDOP:minus NS ;U POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus VERTBAR:| italic-B italic-p CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start R ADDOP:minus R ;U POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus VERTBAR:| italic-B italic-p CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NS ADDOP:minus NS ;T POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus VERTBAR:| italic-B italic-p CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start R ADDOP:minus R ;T POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) PUNCT:,

div.p: and truncated D-branes only involve the untwisted NS-NS and twisted R-R sectors,

semantics.annotation: VERTBAR:| italic-D italic-p CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end ARG:end OPEN:( VERTBAR:| italic-B italic-p CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NS ADDOP:minus NS ;U POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus VERTBAR:| italic-B italic-p CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start R ADDOP:minus R ;T POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) PUNCT:,

div.p: and can only exist for values of pùëùitalic-pp for which a fractional (and bulk) D-brane does not exist. The above spectrum, including the latter restriction, follows from the usual condition that the cylinder amplitude between any two D-branes must correspond to an open string partition function.

In a supersymmetric theory (1) and (2) are BPS states, whereas (3) are non-BPS, but nevertheless stable in certain regimes of the moduli space [12, 13]. To account for the different orientations of the D-branes relative to the action of the orbifold, we denote as in [8] the number of world-volume directions parallel to the fixed-plane by rùëüitalic-rr, and the number of world-volume directions transverse to the fixed-plane by sùë†italic-ss. We shall henceforth label the Dpùëùitalic-pp-branes (and boundary states) by (r,s)ùëüùë†OPEN:( italic-r PUNCT:, italic-s CLOSE:)(r,s), where p=r+sùëùùëüùë†italic-p RELOP:equals italic-r ADDOP:plus italic-sp=r+s. Fractional and truncated branes are either completely localised at the fixed-plane (if s=0ùë†0italic-s RELOP:equals NUMBER:0s=0), or extend in sùë†italic-ss directions transverse to the fixed-plane and terminate at an rùëüitalic-rr-dimensional hyperplane in it; this follows from the fact that the boundary states have components in the twisted sectors.222In the compact case fractional and truncated branes would contain components in multiple twisted sectors, and would therefore be suspended between different fixed planes.

Physical closed string states must be invariant under the GSO-projection and the action of the orbifold group. The spectrum of physical D-branes, i.e. the allowed values of rùëüitalic-rr and sùë†italic-ss for the three types of branes, is therefore determined by the action of the GSO and orbifold operators on the boundary states in the four different sectors. Since these boundary states are generically given by

semantics.annotation: VERTBAR:| italic-B OPEN:( italic-r PUNCT:, italic-s CLOSE:) CLOSE:rangle RELOP:equals italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUMOP:sum OPEN:( ADDOP:plus-or-minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-n ARG:end italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OVERACCENT:widetilde ARG:start italic-alpha ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus-or-minus italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OVERACCENT:widetilde ARG:start italic-psi ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| italic-B OPEN:( italic-r PUNCT:, italic-s CLOSE:) CLOSE:rangle POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,

div.p: the crucial constraint comes from the action of the above operators on the ground states of the different sectors. The left- and right-moving GSO-operators are given as

semantics.annotation: OPEN:( ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:plus-or-minus OPEN:( italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start VERTBAR:| caligraphic-F VERTBAR:| MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) SUMOP:product POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu RELOP:element-of caligraphic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) OPEN:( ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OVERACCENT:widetilde ARG:start italic-f ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:plus-or-minus OPEN:( italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start VERTBAR:| caligraphic-F VERTBAR:| MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) SUMOP:product POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu RELOP:element-of caligraphic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end OVERACCENT:widetilde ARG:start italic-psi ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) PUNCT:,

div.p: where œà0Œºsubscriptsuperscriptùúìùúá0italic-psi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\psi^{\mu}_{0} and œà~0Œºsubscriptsuperscript~ùúìùúá0OVERACCENT:widetilde ARG:start italic-psi ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\widetilde{\psi}^{\mu}_{0} are the left- and right-moving fermionic zero modes, respectively, which satisfy the Clifford algebra

semantics.annotation: OPEN:{ italic-psi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-psi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-nu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:} RELOP:equals italic-eta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-mu italic-nu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:{ italic-psi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, OVERACCENT:widetilde ARG:start italic-psi ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-nu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:} RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 OPEN:{ OVERACCENT:widetilde ARG:start italic-psi ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, OVERACCENT:widetilde ARG:start italic-psi ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-nu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:} RELOP:equals italic-eta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-mu italic-nu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,

div.p: and ‚Ñ±‚Ñ±caligraphic-F{\cal F} denotes the set of coordinates in which the given sector has fermionic zero modes. The prefactor has been fixed (up to a sign) so that both operators square to the identity (we shall only consider the case where the number of elements in ‚Ñ±‚Ñ±caligraphic-F{\cal F}, |‚Ñ±|‚Ñ±VERTBAR:| caligraphic-F VERTBAR:||{\cal F}|, is even). In the untwisted NS-NS sector, for which |‚Ñ±|=0‚Ñ±0VERTBAR:| caligraphic-F VERTBAR:| RELOP:equals NUMBER:0|{\cal F}|=0, it is conventional to take both signs to be -ADDOP:minus-, so that the tachyonic ground state is odd under both operators. For definiteness we adopt this convention for all other sectors as well. Finally, the inversion operator of the orbifold acts as

semantics.annotation: italic-g RELOP:equals SUMOP:product POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu RELOP:element-of caligraphic-F ADDOP:intersection caligraphic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) SUMOP:product POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu RELOP:element-of caligraphic-F ADDOP:intersection caligraphic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end OVERACCENT:widetilde ARG:start italic-psi ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) PUNCT:,

div.p: where ‚Ñõ‚Ñõcaligraphic-R{\cal R} denotes the set of coordinates on which the orbifold acts. Again, the definition of gùëîitalic-gg in the twisted sectors is a priori ambiguous up to a sign; for definiteness we have again fixed this to be +ADDOP:plus+ in all sectors. The resulting actions on the boundary states333One must actually combine boundary states with different spin structures to get GSO-eigenstates; the listed states are the linear combination for which (-1)fsuperscript1ùëìOPEN:( ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end(-1)^{f} has eigenvalue +11ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1+1. are shown in table¬†1 (see [8] for details).

figcaption.span: GSO and orbifold actions on the boundary states.

div.p: The definition of the GSO and orbifold projections in the various sectors determines which of the boundary states are physical, and therefore the D-brane spectrum of the theory. However, in order for this D-brane spectrum to make sense, it must satisfy an additional consistency condition: as a bulk D(r,s)ùëüùë†OPEN:( italic-r PUNCT:, italic-s CLOSE:)(r,s)-brane brane approaches the fixed plane, additional massless scalars usually appear in the world-volume gauge theory; these parametrise the Coulomb branch, and describe the moduli along which the bulk brane fractionates into two fractional branes. In order for this to be possible, the theory must therefore also have a fractional D(r,s)ùëüùë†OPEN:( italic-r PUNCT:, italic-s CLOSE:)(r,s)-brane. As we shall see below, this condition fixes uniquely the ambiguity in defining the GSO-projection in the twisted sectors.

We shall illustrate this condition by considering two examples. The first is Type II on I‚Å¢R4/ùñπ‚Å¢ùñπ2IsuperscriptR4ùñπsubscriptùñπ2I R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide sansserif-Z sansserif-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\rm I\!R}^{4}/{\sf Z\!\!Z}_{2}, which is supersymmetric, and the second is Type 0 on I‚Å¢R6/ùñπ‚Å¢ùñπ2IsuperscriptR6ùñπsubscriptùñπ2I R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide sansserif-Z sansserif-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\rm I\!R}^{6}/{\sf Z\!\!Z}_{2} (or equivalently Type II on I‚Å¢R6/ùñπ‚Å¢ùñπ4IsuperscriptR6ùñπsubscriptùñπ4I R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide sansserif-Z sansserif-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\rm I\!R}^{6}/{\sf Z\!\!Z}_{4}), in which supersymmetry is broken.

Consider Type II strings on I‚Å¢R1,5√óI‚Å¢R4/ùñπ‚Å¢ùñπ2IsuperscriptR15IsuperscriptR4ùñπsubscriptùñπ2I R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:times I R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide sansserif-Z sansserif-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\rm I\!R}^{1,5}\times{\rm I\!R}^{4}/{\sf Z\!\!Z}_{2}, where the generator gùëîitalic-gg of ùñπ‚Å¢ùñπ2ùñπsubscriptùñπ2sansserif-Z sansserif-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\sf Z\!\!Z}_{2} reflects the coordinates x5,x6,x7,x8superscriptùë•5superscriptùë•6superscriptùë•7superscriptùë•8italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:7 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endx^{5},x^{6},x^{7},x^{8}. This breaks S‚Å¢O‚Å¢(1,9)ùëÜùëÇ19italic-S italic-O OPEN:( NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:9 CLOSE:)SO(1,9) to S‚Å¢O‚Å¢(1,5)√óS‚Å¢O‚Å¢(4)RùëÜùëÇ15ùëÜùëÇsubscript4ùëÖitalic-S italic-O OPEN:( NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:5 CLOSE:) MULOP:times italic-S italic-O OPEN:( NUMBER:4 CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:endSO(1,5)\times SO(4)_{R} (S‚Å¢O‚Å¢(4)S√óS‚Å¢O‚Å¢(4)RùëÜùëÇsubscript4ùëÜùëÜùëÇsubscript4ùëÖitalic-S italic-O OPEN:( NUMBER:4 CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:times italic-S italic-O OPEN:( NUMBER:4 CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:endSO(4)_{S}\times SO(4)_{R} in light-cone gauge), where the second factor corresponds to a global R-symmetry from the six-dimensional point of view. For Type IIA the resulting six-dimensional theory has ùí©=(1,1)ùí©11caligraphic-N RELOP:equals OPEN:( NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:1 CLOSE:){\cal N}=(1,1) supersymmetry, and for Type IIB it has ùí©=(2,0)ùí©20caligraphic-N RELOP:equals OPEN:( NUMBER:2 PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 CLOSE:){\cal N}=(2,0) supersymmetry. The relevant properties of the different sectors are shown in table¬†2.

figcaption.span: Oscillator modings in light-cone gauge and ground state charges of the different sectors in the orbifold I‚Å¢R4/ùñπ‚Å¢ùñπ2IsuperscriptR4ùñπsubscriptùñπ2I R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide sansserif-Z sansserif-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\rm I\!R}^{4}/{\sf Z\!\!Z}_{2}. The ground state is tachyonic in the NS;U sector, and massless in all the other sectors. Its charges are determined by quantizing the fermionic zero modes.

div.p: Modular invariance requires that we project all sectors onto states which are even under gùëîitalic-gg,

semantics.annotation: italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-o italic-r italic-b italic-i italic-f italic-o italic-l italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-g CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

div.p: In principle, modular invariance should also determine the correct GSO-projections in the twisted sectors, once that of the untwisted R-R sector has been fixed, i.e. once we have decided whether to start with Type IIA or Type IIB string theory. However, due to the sign ambiguity in the action of the GSO operators on the ground states of these sectors, it is actually difficult to determine the consistent projections. The most general GSO-projections are given as444Only the relative phase of (-1)fsuperscript1ùëìOPEN:( ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end(-1)^{f} and (-1)f~superscript1~ùëìOPEN:( ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OVERACCENT:widetilde ARG:start italic-f ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end(-1)^{\widetilde{f}} is relevant for our purposes:

semantics.annotation: italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-S italic-O POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals OPEN:{ ARRAY:start ROW:start CELL:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:4 ARG:end OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus OPEN:( ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus OPEN:( ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OVERACCENT:widetilde ARG:start italic-f ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) CELL:end CELL:start ATOM:NS-NS;U CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:4 ARG:end OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus OPEN:( ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-epsilon OPEN:( ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OVERACCENT:widetilde ARG:start italic-f ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) CELL:end CELL:start ATOM:R-R;U CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:4 ARG:end OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus OPEN:( ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-eta OPEN:( ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OVERACCENT:widetilde ARG:start italic-f ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) CELL:end CELL:start ATOM:NS-NS;T CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:4 ARG:end OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus OPEN:( ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-delta OPEN:( ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OVERACCENT:widetilde ARG:start italic-f ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) CELL:end CELL:start ATOM:R-R;T PUNCT:, CELL:end ROW:end ARRAY:end

div.p: where œµ,Œ∑,Œ¥=¬±1italic-œµùúÇùõøplus-or-minus1italic-epsilon PUNCT:, italic-eta PUNCT:, italic-delta RELOP:equals ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:1\epsilon,\eta,\delta=\pm 1. The phase œµitalic-œµitalic-epsilon\epsilon corresponds to whether the theory is Type IIA (œµ=-1italic-œµ1italic-epsilon RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1\epsilon=-1) or Type IIB (œµ=+1italic-œµ1italic-epsilon RELOP:equals ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1\epsilon=+1), and the phases Œ∑,Œ¥ùúÇùõøitalic-eta PUNCT:, italic-delta\eta,\delta correspond to the aforementioned ambiguity.

To fix the ambiguity in the choice for Œ∑ùúÇitalic-eta\eta and Œ¥ùõøitalic-delta\delta, let us now consider the D-brane spectrum of the theory. From the projections in the untwisted sectors it follows that the physical bulk D-branes have rùëüitalic-rr even and sùë†italic-ss even in Type IIA, and rùëüitalic-rr odd and sùë†italic-ss even in Type IIB. In order to satisfy the above fractionation condition, there must exist fractional D-branes for the same values of rùëüitalic-rr and sùë†italic-ss. In particular, this means that the corresponding boundary states must be physical in both the twisted NS-NS and the twisted R-R sectors. It follows from the results of Table¬†1 that this requires Œ∑=+1ùúÇ1italic-eta RELOP:equals ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1\eta=+1 and Œ¥=Œ∑‚Å¢œµ=œµùõøùúÇitalic-œµitalic-œµitalic-delta RELOP:equals italic-eta italic-epsilon RELOP:equals italic-epsilon\delta=\eta\epsilon=\epsilon; the D-brane spectrum can then be summarised by

IIA on I‚Å¢R4/Z‚Å¢Z2normal-Isuperscriptnormal-R4normal-Zsubscriptnormal-Z2I R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide sansserif-Z sansserif-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\rm I\!R}^{4}/{\sf Z\!\!Z}_{2}: Fractional and bulk D-branes exist for rùëüitalic-rr and sùë†italic-ss both even.
Truncated D-branes exist for rùëüitalic-rr even and sùë†italic-ss odd, e.g. the non-BPS D-string [12, 13].

li.span: (ii)

div.p:
IIB on I‚Å¢R4/Z‚Å¢Z2normal-Isuperscriptnormal-R4normal-Zsubscriptnormal-Z2I R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide sansserif-Z sansserif-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\rm I\!R}^{4}/{\sf Z\!\!Z}_{2}: Fractional and bulk D-branes exist for rùëüitalic-rr odd and sùë†italic-ss even.
Truncated D-branes exist for both rùëüitalic-rr and sùë†italic-ss odd.

This choice of Œ∑ùúÇitalic-eta\eta and Œ¥ùõøitalic-delta\delta also leads to a supersymmetric spectrum in the twisted sectors. Indeed, the surviving components of the ground state in the twisted R-R sector transform as

semantics.annotation: OPEN:( NUMBER:bold-2 PUNCT:, NUMBER:bold-1 CLOSE:) MULOP:tensor-product OPEN:( NUMBER:bold-2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, NUMBER:bold-1 CLOSE:) RELOP:equals OPEN:( NUMBER:bold-4 PUNCT:, NUMBER:bold-1 CLOSE:)

div.p: in the Type IIA orbifold, and as

semantics.annotation: OPEN:( NUMBER:bold-2 PUNCT:, NUMBER:bold-1 CLOSE:) MULOP:tensor-product OPEN:( NUMBER:bold-2 PUNCT:, NUMBER:bold-1 CLOSE:) RELOP:equals OPEN:( NUMBER:bold-3 PUNCT:, NUMBER:bold-1 CLOSE:) ADDOP:direct-sum OPEN:( NUMBER:bold-1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:bold-1 CLOSE:)

div.p: in the Type IIB orbifold. The former corresponds to the vector component of an ùí©=(1,1)ùí©11caligraphic-N RELOP:equals OPEN:( NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:1 CLOSE:){\cal N}=(1,1) vector multiplet, and the latter to the rank two antisymmetric tensor component and one of the scalar components of an ùí©=(2,0)ùí©20caligraphic-N RELOP:equals OPEN:( NUMBER:2 PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 CLOSE:){\cal N}=(2,0) tensor multiplet. As these are precisely the unbroken supersymmetries associated with the respective theories, the above choice for the GSO-projection in the twisted sectors is consistent with supersymmetry as well.

It may also be worth mentioning that only this choice for the GSO-projection in the twisted sectors leads to an orbifold that can be blown up to a smooth ALE space (K3 in the fully compact case), since the latter is manifestly supersymmetric.

Now consider the case of Type 0 strings on I‚Å¢R1,3√óI‚Å¢R6/ùñπ‚Å¢ùñπ2IsuperscriptR13IsuperscriptR6ùñπsubscriptùñπ2I R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:times I R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide sansserif-Z sansserif-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\rm I\!R}^{1,3}\times{\rm I\!R}^{6}/{\sf Z\!\!Z}_{2}, where the generator gùëîitalic-gg of ùñπ‚Å¢ùñπ2ùñπsubscriptùñπ2sansserif-Z sansserif-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\sf Z\!\!Z}_{2} reflects the six coordinates x3,‚Ä¶,x8superscriptùë•3‚Ä¶superscriptùë•8italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:ldots PUNCT:, italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endx^{3},\ldots,x^{8}.555This case is of particular interest since it is directly related to recent work of Klebanov, Nekrasov and Shatashvili [16], where this orbifold of Type 0B was discussed. Note that g2=(-1)Fsuperscriptùëî2superscript1ùêπitalic-g POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals OPEN:( ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endg^{2}=(-1)^{F}, but since Type 0 is purely bosonic this is equivalent to the identity. In Type II strings gùëîitalic-gg generates a ùñπ‚Å¢ùñπ4ùñπsubscriptùñπ4sansserif-Z sansserif-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\sf Z\!\!Z}_{4} group, so the above theory is identical to Type II on I‚Å¢R1,3√óI‚Å¢R6/ùñπ‚Å¢ùñπ4IsuperscriptR13IsuperscriptR6ùñπsubscriptùñπ4I R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:times I R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide sansserif-Z sansserif-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\rm I\!R}^{1,3}\times{\rm I\!R}^{6}/{\sf Z\!\!Z}_{4}. The ten-dimensional Lorentz group is broken to S‚Å¢O‚Å¢(1,3)√óS‚Å¢O‚Å¢(6)ùëÜùëÇ13ùëÜùëÇ6italic-S italic-O OPEN:( NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:3 CLOSE:) MULOP:times italic-S italic-O OPEN:( NUMBER:6 CLOSE:)SO(1,3)\times SO(6) (S‚Å¢O‚Å¢(2)√óS‚Å¢O‚Å¢(6)ùëÜùëÇ2ùëÜùëÇ6italic-S italic-O OPEN:( NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) MULOP:times italic-S italic-O OPEN:( NUMBER:6 CLOSE:)SO(2)\times SO(6) in light-cone gauge), and the theory is not supersymmetric (and in fact completely fermion-free). The different sectors of the theory are described in table¬†3.

NUMBER:bold-1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:direct-sum NUMBER:bold-1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end

figcaption.span: Oscillator modings and ground state charges of the different sectors in the orbifold I‚Å¢R6/ùñπ‚Å¢ùñπ2IsuperscriptR6ùñπsubscriptùñπ2I R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide sansserif-Z sansserif-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\rm I\!R}^{6}/{\sf Z\!\!Z}_{2}. The ground state is tachyonic in the NS;U sector, massive in the NS;T sector, and massless in the R;U and R;T sectors.

div.p: Since we are using the Type 0 picture, the relevant GSO operator is actually the combination (-1)f+f~superscript1ùëì~ùëìOPEN:( ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-f ADDOP:plus OVERACCENT:widetilde ARG:start italic-f ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end(-1)^{f+\widetilde{f}}. But since the action of (-1)fsuperscript1ùëìOPEN:( ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end(-1)^{f} is trivial on all boundary states, we can still refer to table¬†1 (with n=6ùëõ6italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:6n=6 in this case) for the transformation properties of the boundary states.666In fact, both (-1)fsuperscript1ùëìOPEN:( ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end(-1)^{f} and (-1)f~superscript1~ùëìOPEN:( ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OVERACCENT:widetilde ARG:start italic-f ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end(-1)^{\widetilde{f}} change the spin structure of the boundary states, and the Type 0 GSO operator (-1)f+f~superscript1ùëì~ùëìOPEN:( ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-f ADDOP:plus OVERACCENT:widetilde ARG:start italic-f ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end(-1)^{f+\widetilde{f}} therefore preserves the spin structure. Thus it is not necessary to consider a linear combination of boundary states, and this gives rise to the famous doubling of the D-brane spectrum of Type 0 relative to Type II. The most general GSO-projections are now given by

semantics.annotation: italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-S italic-O POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals OPEN:{ ARRAY:start ROW:start CELL:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus OPEN:( ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-f ADDOP:plus OVERACCENT:widetilde ARG:start italic-f ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) CELL:end CELL:start ATOM:NS-NS CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-epsilon OPEN:( ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-f ADDOP:plus OVERACCENT:widetilde ARG:start italic-f ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) CELL:end CELL:start ATOM:R-R CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-eta OPEN:( ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-f ADDOP:plus OVERACCENT:widetilde ARG:start italic-f ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) CELL:end CELL:start ATOM:NS-NS;T CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-delta OPEN:( ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-f ADDOP:plus OVERACCENT:widetilde ARG:start italic-f ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) CELL:end CELL:start ATOM:R-R;T PUNCT:, CELL:end ROW:end ARRAY:end

div.p: where œµitalic-œµitalic-epsilon\epsilon again determines whether the theory is Type A or B.

Referring again to table¬†1, it now follows that in order to satisfy the D-brane fractionation condition, we must have Œ∑=-1ùúÇ1italic-eta RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1\eta=-1, and Œ¥=Œ∑‚Å¢œµ=-œµùõøùúÇitalic-œµitalic-œµitalic-delta RELOP:equals italic-eta italic-epsilon RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus italic-epsilon\delta=\eta\epsilon=-\epsilon. For this choice (and only for this choice) we obtain a spectrum of D-branes that is consistent with the above fractionation condition; this D-brane spectrum can be summarised by

0A on I‚Å¢R6/Z‚Å¢Z2normal-Isuperscriptnormal-R6normal-Zsubscriptnormal-Z2I R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide sansserif-Z sansserif-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\rm I\!R}^{6}/{\sf Z\!\!Z}_{2}: Fractional and bulk D-branes exist for rùëüitalic-rr and sùë†italic-ss both even.
Truncated D-branes exist for rùëüitalic-rr even and sùë†italic-ss odd.

li.span: (ii)

div.p:
0B on I‚Å¢R6/Z‚Å¢Z2normal-Isuperscriptnormal-R6normal-Zsubscriptnormal-Z2I R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide sansserif-Z sansserif-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\rm I\!R}^{6}/{\sf Z\!\!Z}_{2}: Fractional and bulk D-branes exist for rùëüitalic-rr odd and sùë†italic-ss even.
Truncated D-branes exist for both rùëüitalic-rr and sùë†italic-ss odd.

The above solutions for Œ∑ùúÇitalic-eta\eta and Œ¥ùõøitalic-delta\delta are somewhat counterintuitive, in that the GSO-projection in the twisted sectors is opposite to that in the untwisted sectors. In particular, the projection in the twisted R-R sector is chiral in Type 0A and non-chiral in Type 0B, which is opposite to the convention in the untwisted R-R sector. The surviving massless fields in the twisted R-R sector therefore transform as

semantics.annotation: OPEN:( NUMBER:bold-1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:tensor-product NUMBER:bold-1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) ADDOP:direct-sum OPEN:( NUMBER:bold-1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:tensor-product NUMBER:bold-1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:bold-1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:direct-sum NUMBER:bold-1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end

div.p: in the Type 0A orbifold, and as

semantics.annotation: OPEN:( NUMBER:bold-1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:tensor-product NUMBER:bold-1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) ADDOP:direct-sum OPEN:( NUMBER:bold-1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:tensor-product NUMBER:bold-1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 MULOP:times NUMBER:bold-1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end

div.p: in the Type 0B orbifold. The former corresponds to the two helicities of a massless vector in four dimensions, and the latter to two massless scalars. 777For the case of the Type 0B orbifold, this also agrees with the convention that was considered in [17].

This is the opposite of what was claimed in [16], namely that the twisted sector of the Type 0B orbifold contains a massless vector. In effect, the authors of [16] chose Œ∑=Œ¥=+1ùúÇùõø1italic-eta RELOP:equals italic-delta RELOP:equals ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1\eta=\delta=+1, and therefore a chiral GSO-projection in the twisted R-R sector. It is clear from table¬†1 that in this case there are no physical fractional branes, and therefore that the fractionation condition is violated.

The condition of modular invariance, which underlies all consistent closed string theories, is sometimes clouded by phase ambiguities. This is especially true for the GSO-projection in sectors containing fermionic zero modes. In this note we have explained that there exists a non-perturbative consistency condition for orbifold theories, related to the spectrum of D-branes, that determines the GSO-projection in the twisted sectors uniquely. For the supersymmetric cases, this condition reproduces the conventions that follow from supersymmetry, but it also applies to situations where supersymmetry is broken. As an example of the latter case, we considered Type 0 strings on I‚Å¢R1,3√óI‚Å¢R6/ùñπ‚Å¢ùñπ2IsuperscriptR13IsuperscriptR6ùñπsubscriptùñπ2I R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:times I R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide sansserif-Z sansserif-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\rm I\!R}^{1,3}\times{\rm I\!R}^{6}/{\sf Z\!\!Z}_{2}. In this case, requiring the spectrum of fractional D-branes to match up with that of the bulk D-branes fixes the GSO-projection in the twisted sectors, and thus the spectrum of the theory.

We thank Igor Klebanov for useful correspondences. M.R.G. thanks Peter Goddard for a helpful conversation. O.B. thanks Zurab Kakushadze. O.B. is supported in part by the DOE under grant no. DE-FG03-92-ER 40701. M.R.G. is grateful to the Royal Society for a University Research Fellowship.

J.L. Cardy, Boundary conditions, fusion rules, and the Verlinde formula, Nucl. Phys. B324, 581 (1989).

D. Lewellen, Sewing constraints for conformal field theories on surfaces with boundaries, Nucl. Phys. B372, 654 (1992).
J.L. Cardy, D. Lewellen, Bulk and boundary operators in conformal field theory, Phys. Lett. B259, 274 (1991).
M.R. Gaberdiel, B. Stefa≈Ñski, Dirichlet Branes on Orbifolds, hep-th/9910109.
M.R. Douglas, G. Moore, D-branes, quivers, and ALE instantons, hep-th/9603167.

A. Sen, BPS D-branes on non-supersymmetric cycles, JHEP 9812, 021 (1998); hep-th/9812031.
D-E. Diaconescu, J. Gomis, Fractional branes and boundary states in orbifold theories, hep-th/9906242.
M.R. Gaberdiel, A. Sen, Non-supersymmetric D-Brane configurations with Bose-Fermi degenerate open string spectrum, JHEP 9911, 008 (1999); hep-th/9908060.
